comments.commentBody: I am a liberal who will vote again for Obama because there is no other viable choice. It's hilarious to see the right tear themselves apart over who is pure enough on one issue or another. Immigration, abortion, taxes, "Obamacare," Romney's religion, gay rights,  global warming... I assume they will end up with Mitt because none of the others seem plausible as president. But I guess we shouldn't count out the crazies.

As the day wanes, I feel compelled to make the case for why the Red River Rivalry is the greatest game in the land. And with apologies to DHM, the lonely LONGHORN somewhere in New Jersey, I will try to overcome my annual early October typing tic and capitalize appropriately. (The fact that it has been known to irritate the occasional LONGHORN mitigates its lameness.)

There is no setting in college football that comes close to the OU-TEXAS game. Yes, the Cotton Bowl is a relic, but she has a classic beauty that only comes with age. It has a great facade. And it's loud. And from the upper deck of the east side of the stadium you can see the Dallas skyline to your right and the Ferris wheel and the crazy, whirling rides of the State Fair to your left. Fantastic.

The cacophonous carnival atmosphere surrounding the stadium is impossible to beat.

And then there's the tunnel. I was a poor college student in the '80s who could have never afforded a season ticket, let alone a trip to every away game, so I polished up my trumpet and tried out for the band. Best decision I ever made. Ringside seat, all expenses paid. Going down that tunnel before the game and walking out onto the field and seeing (and hearing) the strange spectacle of a stadium divided exactly in half is something I'll never forget.

And so I am stuck on this game, exactly as it is, for as long as it can last. That's one reason I was so torn over OU's dalliance with the Pac-12. Moving to a different conference wouldn't solve anything. It wouldn't make us hate TEXAS any less and it might take away our yearly chance to pound in their faces. Where's the fun in that?

And as for moving the game out to JerryWorld? Please. That's like moving Christmas to July due to compelling evidence that summer vacation and favorable weather would make for an even bigger economic bonanza.

Leave OU-TEXAS alone. And Boomer Sooner.

[Good job today, Zach. You're a dogged blogger, which is most of the battle.]

What disturbs me is the refusal of the administration to discuss the legal justification for the killing of Mr. al-Awlaki.  The memo -- unlike, say, the Yoo memo justifying "enhanced interrogation techniques" -- strikes this layperson as being pretty reasonable, so why not engage in a public defense of the decision?  Mr. Obama's responsibility to do so is increased by the fact that he accepted the Nobel Peace Prize two years ago.  In doing so, he took on a responsibility that can be in tension with his duties as Commander in Chief, and he owes the world some insight into how he reconciles this tension.
I feel like I am reading an article about the George W. Bush administration.  They are the ones who set the precedent for this.  So much for "hope and change."  Nauseating...

Although killing is regrettable, no matter what the person's citizenship, this case is fundamentally no different from that of anyone killed by law enforcement while trying to commit murder. Al-Awlaki was a self-declared enemy out to kill as many Americans as possible. He personally set in motion plots that, had they succeeded, would have murdered hundreds. To whatever extent this action is controversial, it is only because in the modern age, with non-state actors making war on nations, we can no longer make neat distinctions between police and military action. What does not change, however, is a country's incontrovertible right to defend itself. Al-Awlaki considered tourists and push cart vendors in Times Square to be fair game, and he knew better than some of the posters on this thread that that made HIM fair game. That's why he moved to Yemen.

Thanks to rh27 from California, comment 48, who partially answered my question to Piet Rowayton, comment 31, about “automatically” losing citizenship upon pledging allegiance to any “Foreign Prince or Potentate " or joining any foreign Armed Services. It can be very difficult to relinquish U.S. citizenship (travel.state.gov).

See U.S. Code TITLE 8, CHAPTER 12, SUBCHAPTER III, Part III, § 1481 “Loss of nationality by native-born or naturalized citizen; voluntary action; burden of proof; presumptions.” (http://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/uscode08/usc_sec_08_00001481----000-.h...

Sub-part (b) suggests that there be some sort of hearing at which a citizen may present evidence before citizenship is taken from them: “Any person who commits or performs, or who has committed or performed, any act of expatriation under the provisions of this chapter or any other Act shall be presumed to have done so voluntarily, but such presumption may be rebutted upon a showing, by a preponderance of the evidence, that the act or acts committed or performed were not done voluntarily.”

Sub-part (a)(7) answers the point raised in many comments that this citizen allegedly took up arms against, or plotted the overthrow of, the U.S. and therefore lost his citizenship:

“(a) A person who is a national of the United States whether by birth or naturalization, shall lose his nationality by … (7) committing any act of treason against, or attempting by force to overthrow, or bearing arms against, the United States, … by engaging in a conspiracy to overthrow, put down, or to destroy by force the Government of the United States, or to levy war against them, if and when he is convicted thereof by a court martial or by a court of competent jurisdiction.”

In other words, losing citizenship does not happen automatically, but may follow (a) a hearing to make sure citizenship was relinquished voluntarily or (b) certain convictions by a court martial or by a court of competent jurisdiction.

The US State Department makes very clear on their website that an American can lose his or her citizenship by saying or doing certain things while living abroad, and what al-Awlaki did and said while outside of the US certainly qualified as citizenship-forfeiting activity/speech. Do we in fact know that his citizenship hadn't been stripped from him quietly before his killing? Has the State Dept. been asked point-blank about this?

There is no room for legal debate. The Fifth Amendment states quite clearly that the US government cannot legally kill a citizen (actually, it says "person", but we've decided that foreign people don't count) without due process of law.

What all of these arguments, just like the torture memos several years ago amount to is not "This is legal" but "This is illegal, but we should do it anyway because our targets are Bad People". The whole point of the judicial branch of government is that we're not supposed to trust the executive branch to decide who's a Bad Person and who isn't. Instead, we're all supposed to hear the evidence that the executive branch has that this person is a Bad Person, and a jury of citizens gets to decide whether they're right.

If the Obama administration had wanted to, they could have worked with the Yemeni government (an ally of the US) to attempt to arrest Al-Awlaki. If he had resisted arrest, then by all means use force to take him down. If not, then they could bring him back to the US, and tell a jury about all the bad things he did. And if he was that bad, then there should be no problem obtaining a conviction. And by getting him alive, you get to interrogate him and try to find out everything he knew about terrorism, which enables you to catch more Bad People.

I'd hoped that the murdering of people abroad would stop with Obama and he will not be getting my vote or support. What happened to the U.S.? I believe that the rest of the world is asking that question.
